+Niwa HEK

Background
Intercessory prayer is widely believed to influence recovery from illness, 
but claims of benefits are not supported by well-controlled clinical 
trials. Prior studies have not addressed whether prayer itself or 
knowledge/certainty that prayer is being provided may influence outcome. We 
evaluated whether (1) receiving intercessory prayer or (2) being certain of 
receiving intercessory prayer was associated with uncomplicated recovery 
after coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery.
Methods
Patients at 6 US hospitals were randomly assigned to 1 of 3 groups: 604 
received intercessory prayer after being informed that they may or may not 
receive prayer; 597 did not receive intercessory prayer also after being 
informed that they may or may not receive prayer; and 601 received 
intercessory prayer after being informed they would receive prayer. 
Intercessory prayer was provided for 14 days, starting the night before 
CABG. The primary outcome was presence of any complication within 30 days 
of CABG. Secondary outcomes were any major event and mortality.
Results
In the 2 groups uncertain about receiving intercessory prayer, 
complications occurred in 52% (315/604) of patients who received 
intercessory prayer versus 51% (304/597) of those who did not (relative 
risk 1.02, 95% CI 0.92-1.15). Complications occurred in 59% (352/601) of 
patients certain of receiving intercessory prayer compared with the 52% 
(315/604) of those uncertain of receiving intercessory prayer (relative 
risk 1.14, 95% CI 1.02-1.28). Major events and 30-day mortality were 
similar across the 3 groups.
Conclusions
Intercessory prayer itself had no effect on complication-free recovery from 
CABG, but *certainty of receiving intercessory prayer was associated with a 
HIGHER INCIDENCE of complications.*

There are so many problems with this video it’s difficult to decide where 
to begin.   So I’ll start with the title.  This is not a debate.  This 
video consists of selected clips taken from both the Big Think and Mr. 
Hovind’s seminars.  Mr. Hovind isn’t presenting any scientific hypothesis 
to counter the theory of evolution.  He’s doing what so many creationists 
do best; using propaganda and rhetoric to distort the facts.  He frequently 
quote mines and uses misleading or frankly wrong data to support his claims.

In the description of the video it states Mr. Hovind is currently in prison 
for teaching about his ideas.  This is completely false.  He is in jail for 
tax fraud.  The first amendment guarantees he has the right to speak, or 
preach, about whatever he choses, regardless of the accuracy of his 
teachings.

Now for the worst atrocities of this video, his utter lack of understanding 
of scientific principals.  Starting at 0:14 and continuing for several 
minutes Mr. Hovind makes several inaccurate statements concerning our 
current understanding of the formation of the universe and the development 
of life on earth.   The big bang was not an explosion from nothing as he 
states.  It was a rapid expansion of the universe from a very dense state. 
 All of the matter and energy that composes the universe, as we know it was 
contained in a single point called a singularity.  This is not as Hovind 
states, “Nothing exploded and produced everything.”  Additionally he 
remarks that rain on the rocky crust, created a soup that eventually formed 
life and slowly evolved to everything we see today.  No scientist believes 
that life formed and evolved in this manner.  We really do not know how 
life emerged on this planet, nor do we fully understand the origins of the 
universe, which brings me to my next point.

Starting at 1:17 he states he asked a professor where everything came from 
and the professor said, “I don’t know.”  He continues on in this manner for 
several minutes.  This is the same tactic that many creationist use; 
because not every aspect of a theory is understood…it must be false.  This 
couldn’t be further from the truth.  There are many theories and scientific 
principles that are poorly understood yet we know they are true.  There are 
gaps in our knowledge in every branch of science.  Science doesn’t claim to 
know everything, cannot know everything and will never know everything.  We 
don’t know everything about the theory of gravity, yet we know it’s there 
and you will feel the effects if you jump off the Empire State Building. 
 Doctors do not completely understand how many medications work, yet they 
know the drugs are effective and continue using them to treat patients. 

At 2:12 Hovind asks why two planets spin backwards.  We have a clear 
understanding of why some planetary bodies rotate in different directions 
than the other planets.  There are many reasons a planet my change it’s 
direction of rotation.  It’s poles could flip, tidal forces from the sun 
and other planets may slow and eventually reverse the rotation of the 
planet, or they could have been struck by a large object which we know has 
happened to several planets early in their lives, including our own.  Just 
because the stated professor didn’t know the answers to these questions, 
doesn’t mean that our current model for the creation of the universe or 
planetary evolution is wrong, nor does it prove that the universe was 
created by a “god”.

4:48  There are still monkeys because humans did not evolve from monkeys. 
 Humans and great apes evolved from a common ancestor.  

4:59 Claiming there is no fossil record of the evolution of humans from a 
common ancestor of apes is a common tactic for creationist.  This is 
completely false.  There has been hundreds of fossils found that are 
considered to be “intermediate” or transitional forms of early hominids: 
sivipithicus, australopithicus, homo habilis, and homo erectus to name a 
few.

6:24 Hovind gives an incredibly poor analogy of carbon dating with a 
burning candle.   This demonstrates his utter lack of knowledge of nuclear 
decay.  Carbon 14 decays at a constant rate.   This is a constant, not a 
variable as he states.  Since this decay is constant and we know what the 
abundance of C14 is in living creatures we can very accurately calculate 
the age of the specimen.  He gives examples of errors in radiometric dating 
and even, thankfully, gives citations.  If you look up the references he 
quotes, he’s taking the data out of context.  In two of the examples given 
the articles state that factors in the environment decreased the amount of 
C14 in the specimens.  This does little to decrease the validity of the 
testing method.  What Hovind fails to explain is all forms of testing have 
inaccuracies and environmental factors that can alter the results.  That is 
why scientist use statics to determine a confidence interval and whether 
data is statistically significant.  C14 dating passes these tests almost 
all the time and when there is erroneous data it usually can be accounted 
for and the data adjusted as need.  Hovind shows only a few cases where C14 
gave false results; however, there are thousands of cases where C14 was 
tested, compared to a know control, and shown to be accurate.

7:41, the appendix is a vestigial organ.  It is of lymphoid origin and 
probably had a function at one point in human evolution; likely to protect 
against GI infections.  Today, patient’s who have their appendix removed 
have absolutely no increase in the amount of infections.

9:04, Natural selection will not cause one species to turn into another 
species as his “car into plane” analogy states.  Natural selection allows 
biologic traits to become more or less prominent in a population based on 
the advantage or disadvantage imparted by the trait.  Organisms with 
biologic traits that impart an advantage are more likely to compete for 
food, and mates, and therefore survive to propagate, passing on this 
advantageous trait to the next generation.  Organisms with traits that are 
less advantageous may not be fit enough to compete and therefore may not 
survive to mate and pass on their genetic traits.

9:48, This is an ad homenim fallacy, so what, Earnest Haeckel was a fraud; 
that does nothing to change the validity of evolutionary science or 
embryology.  He continues with an appeal to emotion fallacy by drawing the 
parallel to errors in textbooks with Nazi fascism.  

12:06, This is speculation by a journalist, satirist and philosopher, not a 
scientist.  Plus, from his quote, he clearly doesn’t know the difference 
between a hypothesis and a theory.  As our scientific knowledge increases, 
evolution continues to stand up to all scrutiny.   Some our most astounding 
biologic discoveries since Darwin published the Origin of Species, such as 
Mendelian genetics and DNA, have not only supported the theory; but have 
helped to explain some of the mechanics of how the process works.

Scientific theories are well-substantiated explanations for natural 
phenomenon, which are falsifiable, and based on facts that have been tested 
by repeatable observations and experiments.  Dogma is an ideology laid down 
by an authority as incontrovertible truth.  Creationism (intelligent 
design) is dogma because it is not a well-substantiated explanation for 
natural phenomenon, which has been tested; it is instead an ideology laid 
down by evangelists and ministers as incontrovertible truth.  

Ultimately Mr. Hovind, like so many creationists, is not a scientist and 
has very poor knowledge of physics, chemistry and evolutionary biology.  He 
inaccurately portrays scientific theories and hypotheses, which make his 
entire argument, based on the straw man fallacy and therefore invalid.  ﻿

Let us assume, for the sake of argument, that the Moon is receding at 6

itself. The distance between Earth and Moon oscillates twelve times per 
year between 405,400km at Apogee, and 362,600km at Perigee. That is about

Radiometric dating is a much misunderstood phenomenon. Evolutionists often 
misunderstand the method, assuming it gives a definite age for tested 
samples. Creationists also often misunderstand it, claiming that the 
process is inaccurate.
Radiometric Dating Is Not Inaccurate
Perhaps a good place to start this article would be to affirm that 
radiometric dating is not inaccurate. It is certainly incorrect, and it is 
certainly based on wrong assumptions, but it is not inaccurate.

What do I mean? How can something be accurate and yet wrong? To understand 
this point, we need to understand what exactly is being measured during a 
radiometric dating test. One thing that is not being directly measured is 
the actual age of the sample.
No “Age-Meter”

There is no “age-meter” that you can plug into a rock, giving an immediate 
read-out of the rock’s age. It needs to be remembered that observational 
science can only measure things in the here-and-now, in a manner which can 
be repeated. Historical science is concerned with trying to work out what 
may have happened in a one-off event in the past. Historical science is not 
capable of repetition, checking or peer—˜review. The age of a rock sample 
falls under the heading of historical science, not observational science. 
So what do the observational scientists in the radiometric dating lab do?

Radioactive isotopes are unstable and will decay into more stable isotopes 
of other elements. One common radiometric dating method is the Uranium-Lead 
method. This involves uranium isotopes with an atomic mass of 238. This is 
the most common form of uranium. It decays by a 14-step process into 
lead-206, which is stable. Each step involves the elimination of either an 
alpha or a beta particle.

Therefore the process is:
Uranium Decay Equation
Each individual atom has a chance of decaying by this process. If you were 
able to examine just one atom, you would not know whether or not it would 
decay. The chance of it decaying is not definite, by human standards, and 
is similar to the chance of rolling a particular number on a dice. Although 
we cannot determine what will happen to an individual atom, we can 
determine what will happen to a few million atoms. This is similar to our 
dice analogy.

We cannot tell what number we will roll in any one shake, but if we rolled 
6,000 dice, the chances are very high that 1,000 of them would have landed 
on a six. One dice is unpredictable. Many dice follow a statistically 
predictable pattern. In the same way, one U-238 atom is unpredictable, but 
a sample containing many millions of U-238 atoms will be very predictable.

What happens statistically is that half of the available atoms will have 
decayed in a given period, specific to each radioactive species, called the 
half-life. For example, if element Aa had a half-life of 1 day and we had 
1,000 lbs. of it on Monday, then we would have 500 lbs. on Tuesday, 250 
lbs. (half of 500) on Wednesday and 125 lbs. on Thursday.

Determining Half-Life
By observing how fast U-238 decays into lead-206, we can calculate the 
half-life of U-238. This is a theoretical calculation, and we can therefore 
determine that the half-life of U-238 is 4.5 billion years. Remember that 
the half-life is a statistical measure. Granting that U-238 has a half-life 
of 4.5 billion years in no way negates the idea that the Earth is only 
6,000 years old.

A very common rock that contains U-238 is granite. If we look at some of 
the very small zircon crystals in granite, we can accurately measure how 
much U-238 and Pb-206 the crystal contains. In order to calculate the age 
of the rock, we need three other pieces of information:

We need to know how fast the U-238 turns into Pb-206. The half-life gives 
us this value, provided the half-life has never altered during the lifetime 
of the zircon crystal.
We need to know how much Pb-206 there was in the original rock. This is 
clearly impossible. It is usually assumed, without justification, that the 
original quantity of Pb-206 in the rock was zero.

We need to be sure that no lead compounds have been added to or taken away 
from the rock. Given that lead compounds are fairly soluble in water, this 
is something that we cannot be very sure of.
Using the above assumptions, it is calculated that the zircon crystals have 
an age of about 1.5 billion years.

Based Upon Assumptions
The radioactive decay process above can be seen to produce 8 
alpha-particles for each one atom of U-238. Each ÃŽÂ±-particle could gain 
new electrons and become an atom of helium. The rate of diffusion of helium 
from a zircon crustal can be measured. It turns out that this rate of 
diffusion of helium is compatible with the crystals being about 5,000 years 
old, not 1.5 billion years old. Although assumptions 2 and 3 are not 
provable, they actually seem very likely in this particular example. 
Therefore, it seems that the first assumption must be wrong1.

Remember that we have already said that these experimenters are highly 
skilled. It is therefore unlikely that the laboratory technicians have made 
a mistake in their measurements of U-238 or Pb-206. The only possible 
conclusion, therefore, is that the half-life of U-238 has not been constant 
throughout the lifetime of the granite and its zircon crystals.

I forced myself to watch Mr. Hovind's entire video and here are just some 
of the things I pulled out of it:

1) The singularity which began expanding with the 'Big Bang' was not 
believed to be spinning. He actually cited his evidence and it was 
referring to the formation of a star system.  Incidentally, star systems 
don't explode when they form so conservation of angular momentum doesn't 
apply.
2) Abiogenesis (that would be scientific exploration of the origin of life) 
never claims that life came from rocks.  That's a fabrication Mr. Hovind 
made up to unfairly discredit science. 
3) In an attempt to disprove the scientific evidence of abiogenesis, Mr. 
Hovind says that there was too much oxygen on the planet for life to form 
and cites oxygen bubbles formed in amber.  Amber, as is commonly known, is 
formed from tree sap.  Trees, one may expect, came after life began.
4) He lies about Stephen J. Gould, calling him a "Marxist professor."  
Gould's father was a Marxist, but Stephen had very different beliefs from 
his father and was not a Marxist.
5) Speaking of Gould, Mr. Hovind quote-mines Gould, making it seem that he 
says a lack of transitional fossils is a problem with evolution when Gould 
was actually saying that the lack of transitional fossils was a problem for 
gradual evolution.  Gould was pointing out that life didn't steadily 
change, but rather that it surged forward for periods and held steady for 
others.
6) He makes the claim that an artificial dam 4000 years ago broke and all 
the rushing water formed the grand canyon.  Of course, that would mean 
there would be evidence of the dam such as shaped stone blocks or a quarry 
where they originated.
7) He points out that if the flood was real, there would be layers of dirt 
and that they would separate by the composition.  His example lists gravel, 
sand, silt, and clay.  Of course, the layers are not laid out like that so 
he's arguing against the flood.
8) He doesn't understand radiocarbon dating at all or if he does, he lies 
about it.  He builds a straw man with the line "We know the Earth is 
millions of years old because of carbon dating," and then proceeds to tear 
it down.  Of course, carbon dating is shown to be only usable to periods of 
time no more than 75,000 years old so anyone who actually understands 
carbon dating would never make that claim.

+Herr Zweistein Usually when I see a reply like this, I do not respond 
because it is so full of error that it is difficult to respond to. But 
because you were polite and seemed honest, I will give it a try. But 
please, know that your level of knowledge on these subjects is very lacking

So, on to the task at hand...
You said: Abiogenesis has NOTHING to do with evolution. 
My reply: I was pointing out that, while they are different scientific 
theories, they do have something to do with each other. So you were 
overstating your case when you said they have NOTHING to do with each 
other. They both attempt to explain and account for life in a naturalistic 
and materialistic way, and they are both talked about and taught in biology 
classes. Yes, everybody knows that technically they are two separate 
theories, but they so have a significant relationship. It isn't like 
talking about the theory of Gravity and the Germ Theory of Disease - those 
two things have NOTHING to do with each other; whereas, Abiogenesis and 
Darwinian Evolution have much more to do with each other. The reason why 
people like to completely separate them is because with Abiogenesis, they 
strain so very hard as to loose credibility when they try to talk about it 
scientifically and claim that the theory is true and sound. So when the 
obvious errors and assumptions are brought out with Abiogenesis, those same 
errors and assumptions easily carry over into Darwinian Evolution, and 
evolutionists don't like that. 
So you are correct if you say, Abiogenesis and Darwinian Evolution are two 
different theories, but don't say they have NOTHING to do with each other. 
By doing this you sound overzealous in the same way a religious person 
sounds when they make overstated claims about God.

You say: Only because we do not know where life came from doesn't mean we 
don't know how it evolved.
My reply: Obviously this is true by definition. But in practice/reality, we 
don't know how life started, and we don't know how it evolved. NeoDarwinian 
Evolution attempts to provide a mechanism for how it happened, but I think 
that in the same way you don't know how life started, you don't know how it 
evolved. You can see how scientists attempt to deal with Abiogenesis, and 
its obvious failures. Take that same view and move it to Darwinian 
Evolution and you can see how that theory falls short as well. You don't 
have to be afraid of being dumb or unscientific if you start to doubt 
Darwinain Evolution. I know lots of doctors, teachers with masters degrees 
in science and biology, and other people like this that all don't believe 
that Darwinian Evolution can explain what we observe in life. Despite what 
some or most evolutionists say, there are good reasons for this. We will 
basically all admit that it is a good theory in a lot of ways, but that 
upon critical analysis, it does seem to lack the ability to account for 
much of life. I know that I didn't get into detail about this or provide 
any examples, (if you want we can address that later) but just realize that 
in the same way Abiogenesis fails, so does Darwinian Evolution.

You say: By evolution you mean "change over time". But that definition is 
too simple and broad to really explain what is meant by evolution. That is 
saying something that is very small and simple and nobody argues with and 
then saying because that is true, that everything else that Darwinian 
Evolution claims is true. That is like saying that going to the moon is 
lifting off the surface of the earth. Then talking about and showing 
millions of examples of people jumping up into the air, flying in a hot air 
balloon, and flying in an airplane - then assuming that you have 
scientifically shown how to get to the moon. 
To put it another way, "change over time" is demonstrated in a single 
generation. When a human mother and father have a baby, there is a change 
that occurs over that time. The baby has different genes than the father 
has and different ones than the mother. It also looks different than either 
the mother or the father, so change has occurred over a short time. But you 
can see how this doesn't explain or account for the entire biosphere from 
the simplest self-replicating molecule. To include more time and more 
change, like selectively breeding a Golden Lab from a common dog ancestor 
shows more change over a greater amount of time. That is often confused for 
showing Darwinian Evolution in the same way Darwinian Evolution attempts to 
account for all of life. Breeding a dog is the manipulation of gene 
expression. The genes already existed in the original and they were just 
specially selected for various configurations of expression. But that 
doesn't account for how the original dog ancestor came to be in the first 
place. So saying evolution is "change over time" is a bait-and-switch 
technique. It hooks you in to believing a small aspect of the theory and 
then tricks you into believing everything about the theory. It's like a car 
salesman advertising that he is selling a car for $5, but then when you get 
there to buy it, he only has cars available for $5,000. You would instantly 
know that something wasn't right. (if you want we can discuss specific 
examples of evolution in later posts if you have questions about them).

You say: Evolution isn't necessarily gain, but yes in most creatures gain 
happened, but this isn't the aim of evolution. 
My reply: Your kind of missing the point and talking in circles. If you 
start with a single self-replicating molecule and then go to a modern 
creature like a human, a HUGE amount of gain happened. This is true with 
EVERY creature alive today. So Darwinian Evolution necessarily attempts to 
explain how that massive amount of gain happened. Again we have this 
bait-and-switch technique when we talk about evolution not necessarily 
being gain. We all know that some change, which can be called evolution, 
can occur by changing gene expression without gaining information. This 
same evolution can occur if information is lost (a fish that loses its eyes 
if it lives in a dark cave).  And we know that supposed evolution doesn't 
have an aim. But you can't talk about these small lateral changes brought 
about by gene expression or the loss of genes and then make the leap that 
because that occurs, Darwinian Evolution can easily account for the entire 
biosphere of biological information. Again, that's bait-and-switch. That 
would be like claiming that I know how to get to Tom Cruise's house, 
exactly - and proving it to you by saying, watch me move. I can move a 
little left and a little right. I can walk forward and backwards. You see, 
in order to travel, I don't NECESSARILY have a direction in mind. And by 
the way, because I showed you all of this movement, I scientifically showed 
you that I did indeed got to Tom Cruise's house. (remember that analogies 
and metaphors aren't exact representations, they show a point, but break 
down fairly quickly - so don't get hung up on it.)

You say: You cannot change the past, dealing with falsehoods that were

lies. They are taught for decades after they are known to be lies. It is

out of the teachings. This is human behavior. It is psychological, social, 
and political. All these human characteristics play into science and its 
teachings as well. One is ignorant not to understand this. So, most people 
try to hold "science" up as a perfect system of mathematical/robotic 
calculation, (like the terminator - it feels no pain, it cannot be 
bargained with, it cannot be reasoned with, it feels no pity or remorse,

is a lot of money, power, prestige, and pride that comes along with it. 
There is a lot of politics and philosophy that come into science. This is 
not some small, passing point; it is the very nature of the process that we 
are talking about.

AFTER life already started, then yes; abiogenesis would fall outside that 
boundary. But, if you are talking about life/biology, life and biology 
sciences, and theories about life and how it came to be. Then abiogenesis 
is a part of that. And in a lot of biology/science textbooks, you will find

configuration/information that was working then, compared to what we see 
today there is MASSIVE gain that must be accounted for. That gain is 
attempted to be accounted for with the theory of evolution. You are correct 
that evolution isn't necessarily a gain; it can be only change without 
gain. It can even be loss in some cases. But, those specific instances do 
not exclude nor negate what the theory of evolution is attempting to 
explain, and that is A LOT OF GAIN. You are using a logical fallacy here.

Waw, Hovid doesn't understand evolution at all...
In evolution:
1) Organisms' organs and genes degenerate.
2) Organisms' organs and genes mutate.
3) Beneficial mutations are passed on and non-beneficial mutations are 
selected against.
4) Finally, non-useful or non-influential organs continue to degenerate 
until you're left with a vestigial organ.

Animals don't become "better", but rather more fit to survive in their 
environment. Animals that don't adapt quick enough, die off and become 
instinct. Monkeys still exist because evolution suggests monkeys and humans 
share a common ancestor that is actually instinct, but that looked a lot 
like a monkey.

Even so, saying why monkeys still exist is like asking why the British or 
most Europeans still exist.(Them being the ancestors of most 
north-americans)

Also, the ancestry part is a lot like language. Its not like one day a 
child from a latin speaking mother started speaking french or spanish. 
Changes happen gradually and over the whole group(gene pool). When the 
environment changes, the individuals more fit in the gene pool, continue 
on. Just as the english language today is far different than what it was 
500 years ago, the same happens to organisms, just at a far slower rate.﻿

+Jason am By that same logic the scientific theory of plate tectonics are 
not science either. Actually, you'd have to remove everything from string 
theory to germ theory and pretty much the entire field of geology (to 
mention some) if direct observation in the moment and with the naked eye 
are the only criteria for being scientific. You forget that there are other 
ways of observing and testing than sitting down and look at something.
For example, one way to test a scientific theory is to use it to make 
predictions. By the laws presented in the theory of evolution, distribution 
of a species should cause intermediate species to leave fossils in areas 
between their ancestors and their descendants. This method of predicting 
where to find fossils of intermediate species has been used countless times 
and has been very successful. Another test is that since the laws presented 
in the theory of evolution states that all life on earth is related, it 
should be possible to build an evolutionary family tree for all organisms 
here. Doing so has enabled us to find out everything from migration 
patterns of land animals to the origin point for the AIDS virus.
Farmers and breeders have also used the process of selecting crop and 
animals among variation among offspring to make new plants and animal 
breeds, like cauliflower, broccoli, cabbage, lettuce, chiuauas and saint 
bernards. The difference between this and the kind of selection that 
happens in nature is that human preference, while in nature it's preditors, 
climate, landscape, chemicals and so on that selects which individuals are 
allowed to have offspring.
These are just a few examples of how the theory of evolution can be and has 
been tested. And don't say "that's not what evolution is" because that IS 
what evolution is. It's "change in heritable traits of biological 
populations over successive generations", like when a wolf changes into a 
chiuaua over several generations.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution

conclusions are often not always absolute.  As new technologies in science 
emerge, so do new theories that can change what was previously concluded.  
The point is, science is always evolving (pun intended).

believe in a Creator.  However, you all need to stop taking the Bible as 
LITERAL TRUTH.  You need to stop listening to people like Hovind and Ken 
Ham (Creationist Museum) and look at the science that they are misquoting.  
For example, Hovind is right in saying that carbon-dating cannot tell you 
how old fossils are.  What he does NOT tell you is that it is NOT USED for 
fossils!  Fossils are PETRIFIED!  Carbon-dating is only used on previously 
living tissue that are less than 50,000 years old.  There are OTHER methods 
of dating that uses the isotopes of other elements depending on their 
half-life, which range from 0.7 years to 1.3 billion years and CAN be used 
on inorganic material, such as rock.  Therefore, dating fossils can support 
the conclusion that animals existed before the Biblical account of Adam and 
Eve.  I'm not going to say that the Bible is a falsehood, but the science

Throughout history, snake oil salesmen use the same fast-talking technique 
to convince the questionably discerning that his rapid-fire nonsense is 
somehow "fact".  Balderdash!  I had him pegged as a shyster from the moment 
he opened his mouth.  Then he started going on about "Why do some moons 
rotate backwards?"

Nits like this tend to think on a purely human level, without considering 
that events in our own universe happen at an immense scale that requires a 
wider, more encompassing point of view.  So let me scale it down to 
something his brain can grasp and something that has been demonstrated in 
beer halls all over the US time and time again.  If you strike a pool ball 
with a cue stick below the center point of the ball, at just the right 
degree, you can in fact, impart a reverse spin on the ball while also 
propelling it forward.  I've done this myself, I rarely play billiards.  
(Even Tom and Jerry have done this one in the cartoons!)  Now, remove all 
the resistance of the table and the air, and you will have a ball moving 
endlessly forward while spinning backwards.  Now scale it up to near planet 
size, and add in a parent planet's gravity field.  Viola!  Moon spinning 
backward in orbit!  But wait!  What gave it that backward spin?  Remember 
the pool cue?  Well, it turns out that some moons were struck off of other 
parent bodies in ancient collisions with other objects.  Say two 
planet-sized asteroids collide while drifting in space, and one or even 
both, break into fragments.  Those fragments are just like pool balls, 
scattering across the table in every direction, hitting other objects, 
randomly changing speed and rotation, until they spin a bit too close to 
another planetary body.  Both are spinning, and we all know that moving 
things can generate effects like current and magnetism, so the fragment, 
now covered with a thick layer of dust it has attracted to itself during 
its wandering, finds itself gradually pulled into a path that takes it 
around the planet.  Many such pairings don't end up well, and the orbit 
isn't quite right, so the moon goes spinning off into space, since the 
gravitational pull of the planet didn't hold it captive.  But some moons do 
get roped into orbits, and even retaining their backward spin, they now 
take a millennial path around its new parent planet. 

If anything, gravity is the one thing science hasn't quite explained yet, 
but, give us time, we've only been really working on the problem a few 
hundred years.  Turns out it's really hard to recreate gravity's effects in 
a lab.  It isn't just "magnetism", since not everything is metal.  Just 
exactly what gravity does is not yet well understood.

So Mr. Hovind, who claims to have "taught" science, doesn't know why a moon 
can rotate backwards?  Any person claiming the title of science teacher, 
should have the basics of planetary interaction down before attempting to 
teach others, right?  Right?

Now I understand why Bill Nye sighed with worn patience about prevaricators 
like this Hovind fellow.  He knows that those who embrace religion rarely 
if ever want that belief shaken, and will simply not even consider another 
point of view, even while asking "Why does this work this way?"  Nope, they 
just talk faster and louder, like a clueless American tourist in far 
eastern country, sure that the natives will 'get it' if they butcher the 
language by adding more vowels and shouting their questions.  It's exactly 
the same.

Science and those who study its various field admits when we don't know for 
sure how things work.  After all, we're just beginning as a species, let 
alone getting a handle on why the skies are filled with more galaxies than 
we can count.  And no, scientists don't know why all those galaxies and 
stars are moving away from one central point, and have been since time 
began.  We can't be expected to grasp that one yet, given the scant few 
thousand years "modern" man has been around.  All the sciences readily 
admit they still have a lot of work to do, and endless things to discover 
and understand, but with what we DO know, we can verify some of our 
conclusions.

One example, which supports the story of the wandering moons is the tale of 
the Martian meteorites.  There are a few meteorites here on earth that 
don't conform to the usual spectrum of materials on expects to see in such 
rocks.  One such meteorite, ALH84001, is a stone believed to have come from 
Mars.  This was because spectral analysis done on both the rock and Mars 
are very measurable, and very similar.  But we couldn't know for sure until 
we had advanced enough to send robots there with and onboard chemical 
lab.   That lab, after successfully making the multi-year trip to the red 
planet, managed to grind off some dust from a rock and analyze it, 
verifying scientific theory that ALH84001 is not only the same composition 
as Mars, but it also was pushed off the planet by some past impact.  Shot 
into space, it eventually slid into Earth's gravitatonal pull.  Until 
proven otherwise, this formula for what happened is science's best theory, 
and it's unlikely to change unless some one comes up with more data that 
proves otherwise.  Bill Nye, Neils de Grasse Tyson, Carl Sagan, Einstein, 
Galileo, Sir Isaac Newton, Enrico Fermi, Robert Wilson, Leon Lederman, and 
so many other learned men have no problem "getting it", so why is Mr. 
Hovind having so much trouble?  Well, it reminds me of what my old science 
teacher used to tell me:  He said, "You know, you'd be pretty likely to get 
good or better grades if you just apply yourself."﻿

Carbon dating is a sub-category of radiometric dating.  Hovind apparently 
has no clue as to what radiocarbon dating is, especially since he's

fossil. 

Radiocarbon dating is usually accurate up to around 50,000 years; in a 
few cases it can be used to date into the 100,000-year range.  Dinosaur 
fossils begin around 65 million years ago.

Most fossils - early Pleistocene mammals (that's mammoths, sabre-tooth 
cats, prehistoric giant bison, etc.) Pliocene mammals, all the way back 
into the Cretaceous-Jurassic-Triassic dinosaur eras, & earlier - must be 
dated using OTHER radioactive elements decay rates.﻿

I am not saying that the only things that are true are those things which

can not distinguish between something that is plausibly true and something 
that is made up.

If there is no evidence for a worldwide flood, how can I distinguish that 
story from any other ancient (or modern) story?  The Grand Canyon is often 
offered as evidence.  However, flood waters carve straight paths.  This can 
be tested as well as observed when floods occur.  On the other hand, rivers 
meander.  This can also be observed.  The Grand Canyon takes a path that 
meanders and is not straight.  The evidence is that it was carved by a 
river.

While god can do whatever he wants, what's the difference between a 
worldwide flood claim and any other story?

As for morality.  Consider that my sister and I have very similar genes and 
that she has children but I do not.

In the first scenario, let's assume that I have genes that express 
empathetic behaviors such that I help take care of my sister's kids in some 
way.  Because my sister and I share similar DNA, it is likely she will also 
have empathetic genes as well as her children.  Even though I am not 
directly passing on the gene, the behaviors that the genes express can 
contribute the gene being passed on by my sibling.  Thus, the gene is 
likely to propagate throughout a population.

In the second scenario, let's assume I do not have genes that express 
empathetic behavior.  I do not help my sister with her children.  Again, 
since my sister and I share similar DNA, she and her children will not have 
the gene either.  Her children will not benefit from empathetic behavior of 
close relatives.

The first scenario is likely to have a better survival rate than the second 
scenario.  Moral behavior is often beneficial to the survival of our 
species.  We're here because we express behavior that helped our ancestors 
and us survive in

+islandonlinenews 
Now, now... Shouting about lies when it's a fact (evolution happened and is 
happening) and it is a theory (an explanation of the fact). By the way, in 
science, a theory cannot be fact. It can only be highly likely. For what 
it's worth, this also means that in science, a theory cannot be a lie. (*Sucks 
to be you*.)

My guess is that you haven't a clue about the difference, or that theory 
cannot be fact, much less a lie. Let me explain.

Charles Darwin's *grandfather*, Erasmus Darwin knew (as did every other 
educated person back then, or they could have simply looked at a cut 
through a bed of sedimentary rock) the fact that species had changed over 
time. After all, there was a rather remarkable dearth of dinosaurs walking 
around late eighteenth century and early nineteenth century Britain. That 
is a fact. Also remarkable, there is *still* a dearth of said dinosaurs 
walking around. 

(Full disclosure; there are dinosaurs walking around various Creation 
Museums but these are not ancient dinosaurs. These are modern dinosaurs.)

Erasmus Darwin tried to explain this change in species. He came up with a 
theory (an explanation) that was shall we say as kindly as possible, 
bat-shit crazy. It was titled *Zoonomia; or the Laws of Organic Life* 
(1794). 

Charles Darwin also wanted to explain how species change over time. He 
figured out that random changes (now called mutations) acted on by 
non-random natural selection (beneficial changes gave an organism an 
increased success at passing on those changes; more surviving offspring) 
over vast periods of time (take this to mean more than roughly 6000 years) 
is the explanation for change in species. 

He published this theory in his book *On The Origins Of Species* (1859). 

So far, everything known to be fact in biology supports Darwin's theory. 
Yes, the theory has been advanced considerably with modern knowledge, but 
Darwin did get it right. Furthermore, nothing known to be fact in biology 
contradicts the theory.

As the title of a 1973 essay by the evolutionary biologist *and Russian 
Orthodox Christian* Theodosius Dobzhansky says, ""Nothing in Biology Makes 
Sense Except in the Light of Evolution".

In science, a theory cannot be fact because tomorrow, new information 
(fact) my call the theory into question or call for it's outright 
dismissal. New information is constantly calling for refinement of theory, 
a reworking of certain nuance at the cutting edge of theory and on rare 
occasions, complete overthrow of theory and the need for new theory.

My guess is that you are a religious person, so I'm assuming you have no 
clue why, in science, this is a *good* thing. 

Hint; if it was a bad thing, science would accept that every fossil in the 
ground was the result of a world-wide flood about 6000 years ago. Guess 
what...???

The peer-reviewed scientific output from the creationist movement is very 
low, especially considering the long history and generous funding of the 
movement.  In a survey of editors of sixty-eight journals, even by the most 
generous criteria, only eighteen out of an estimated 135,000 submissions 
were found that could be described as advocating creationism. One week's 
worth of peer-reviewed papers on evolutionary biology exceeds the entire 
history of creationism peer-review.

Virtually none of the papers show any original research.

The point which discredits creationism, is not that it has few 
peer-reviewed papers, but why there are so few. Creationism proponents 
appear to have no interest in conducting original research that would be 
appropriate for peer-reviewed journals, and other researchers see nothing

Examples of Speciation (Macro-evolution):

*Plants through hybridization:*
"While studying the genetics of the evening primrose, Oenothera 
lamarckiana, de Vries (1905) found an unusual variant among his plants. O. 
lamarckiana has a chromosome number of 2N = 14. The variant had a 
chromosome number of 2N = 28. He found that he was unable to breed this 
variant with O. lamarckiana. He named this new species O. gigas."

"Digby (1912) crossed the primrose species Primula verticillata and P. 
floribunda to produce a sterile hybrid. Polyploidization occurred in a few 
of these plants to produce fertile offspring. The new species was named P. 
kewensis. Newton and Pellew (1929) note that spontaneous hybrids of P. 
verticillata and P. floribunda set tetraploid seed on at least three 
occasions. These happened in 1905, 1923 and 1926."

"Owenby (1950) demonstrated that two species in this genus were produced by 
polyploidization from hybrids. She showed that Trapopogonan miscellus found 
in a colony in Moscow, Idaho was produced by hybridization of T. dubius and 
T. pratensis. She also showed that T. mirus found in a colony near Pullman, 
Washington was produced by hybridization of T. dubius and T. porrifolius."

"The Russian cytologist Karpchenko (1928) crossed the radish, Raphanus 
sativus, with the cabbage, Brassica oleracea. Despite the fact that the 
plants were in different genera, he got a sterile hybrid. Some unreduced 
gametes were formed in the hybrids. This allowed for the production of 
seed. Plants grown from the seeds were interfertile with each other. They 
were not interfertile with either parental species. Unfortunately the new 
plant (genus Raphanobrassica) had the foliage of a radish and the root of a 
cabbage."

"A species of hemp nettle, Galeopsis tetrahit, was hypothesized to be the 
result of a natural hybridization of two other species, G. pubescens and G. 
speciosa (Muntzing 1932). The two species were crossed. The hybrids matched 
G. tetrahit in both visible features and chromosome morplology."

*Plants not through hybridization:*
"Gottlieb (1973) documented the speciation of Stephanomeira malheurensis. 
He found a single small population (< 250 plants) among a much larger 
population (> 25,000 plants) of S. exigua in Harney Co., Oregon. Both 
species are diploid and have the same number of chromosomes (N = 8). S. 
exigua is an obligate outcrosser exhibiting sporophytic 
self-incompatibility. S. malheurensis exhibits no self- incompatibility and 
self-pollinates. Though the two species look very similar, Gottlieb was 
able to document morphological differences in five characters plus 
chromosomal differences. F1 hybrids between the species produces only 50% 
of the seeds and 24% of the pollen that conspecific crosses produced. F2 
hybrids showed various developmental abnormalities."

"Pasterniani (1969) produced almost complete reproductive isolation between 
two varieties of maize. The varieties were distinguishable by seed color, 
white versus yellow. Other genetic markers allowed him to identify hybrids. 
The two varieties were planted in a common field. Any plant's nearest 
neighbors were always plants of the other strain. Selection was applied 
against hybridization by using only those ears of corn that showed a low 
degree of hybridi- zation as the source of the next years seed. Only 
parental type kernels from these ears were planted. The strength of 
selection was increased each year. In the first year, only ears with less 
than 30% intercrossed seed were used. In the fifth year, only ears with 
less than 1% intercrossed seed were used. After five years the average 
percentage of intercrossed matings dropped from 35.8% to 4.9% in the white 
strain and from 46.7% to 3.4% in the yellow strain."

*Fruit Flies:*
"Dobzhansky and Pavlovsky (1971) reported a speciation event that occurred 
in a laboratory culture of Drosophila paulistorum sometime between 1958 and 
1963. The culture was descended from a single inseminated female that was 
captured in the Llanos of Colombia. In 1958 this strain produced fertile 
hybrids when crossed with conspecifics of different strains from Orinocan. 
From 1963 onward crosses with Orinocan strains produced only sterile males. 
Initially no assortative mating or behavioral isolation was seen between 
the Llanos strain and the Orinocan strains. Later on Dobzhansky produced 
assortative mating (Dobzhansky 1972)."

"Thoday and Gibson (1962) established a population of Drosophila 
melanogaster from four gravid females. They applied selection on this 
population for flies with the highest and lowest numbers of sternoplural 
chaetae (hairs). In each generation, eight flies with high numbers of 
chaetae were allowed to interbreed and eight flies with low numbers of 
chaetae were allowed to interbreed. Periodically they performed mate choice 
experiments on the two lines. They found that they had produced a high 
degree of positive assortative mating between the two groups. In the decade 
or so following this, eighteen labs attempted unsuccessfully to reproduce 
these results. References are given in Thoday and Gibson 1970."

"Crossley (1974) was able to produce changes in mating behavior in two 
mutant strains of D. melanogaster. Four treatments were used. In each 
treatment, 55 virgin males and 55 virgin females of both ebony body mutant 
flies and vestigial wing mutant flies (220 flies total) were put into a jar 
and allowed to mate for 20 hours. The females were collected and each was 
put into a separate vial. The phenotypes of the offspring were recorded. 
Wild type offspring were hybrids between the mutants. In two of the four 
treatments, mating was carried out in the light. In one of these treatments 
all hybrid offspring were destroyed. This was repeated for 40 generations. 
Mating was carried out in the dark in the other two treatments. Again, in 
one of these all hybrids were destroyed. This was repeated for 49 
generations. Crossley ran mate choice tests and observed mating behavior. 
Positive assortative mating was found in the treatment which had mated in 
the light and had been subject to strong selection against hybridization. 
The basis of this was changes in the courtship behaviors of both sexes. 
Similar experiments, without observation of mating behavior, were performed 
by Knight, et. al. (1956)."

"Kilias, et. al. (1980) exposed D. melanogaster populations to different 
temperature and humidity regimes for several years. They performed mating 
tests to check for reproductive isolation. They found some sterility in 
crosses among populations raised under different conditions. They also 
showed some positive assortative mating. These things were not observed in 
populations which were separated but raised under the same conditions. They 
concluded that sexual isolation was produced as a byproduct of selection."

"In a series of papers (Rice 1985, Rice and Salt 1988 and Rice and Salt 
1990) Rice and Salt presented experimental evidence for the possiblility of 
sympatric speciation. They started from the premise that whenever organisms 
sort themselves into the environment first and then mate locally, 
individuals with the same habitat preferences will necessarily mate 
assortatively. They established a stock population of D. melanogaster with 
flies collected in an orchard near Davis, California. Pupae from the 
culture were placed into a habitat maze. Newly emerged flies had to 
negotiate the maze to find food. The maze simulated several environmental 
gradients simultaneously. The flies had to make three choices of which way 
to go. The first was between light and dark (phototaxis). The second was 
between up and down (geotaxis). The last was between the scent of 
acetaldehyde and the scent of ethanol (chemotaxis). This divided the flies 
among eight habitats. The flies were further divided by the time of day of 
emergence. In total the flies were divided among 24 spatio-temporal 
habitats.

They next cultured two strains of flies that had chosen opposite habitats. 
One strain emerged early, flew upward and was attracted to dark and 
acetaldehyde. The other emerged late, flew downward and was attracted to 
light and ethanol. Pupae from these two strains were placed together in the 
maze. They were allowed to mate at the food site and were collected. Eye 
color differences between the strains allowed Rice and Salt to distinguish 
between the two strains. A selective penalty was imposed on flies that 
switched habitats. Females that switched habitats were destroyed. None of 
their gametes passed into the next generation. Males that switched habitats 
received no penalty. After 25 generations of this mating tests showed 
reproductive isolation between the two strains. Habitat specialization was 
also produced.

They next repeated the experiment without the penalty against habitat 
switching. The result was the same -- reproductive isolation was produced. 
They argued that a switching penalty is not necessary to produce 
reproductive isolation. Their results, they stated, show the possibility of 
sympatric speciation."

"In a series of experiments, del Solar (1966) derived positively and 
negatively geotactic and phototactic strains of D. pseudoobscura from the 
same population by running the flies through mazes. Flies from different 
strains were then introduced into mating chambers (10 males and 10 females 
from each strain). Matings were recorded. Significant positive assortative 
mating was found."

"The founder-flush (a.k.a. flush-crash) hypothesis posits that genetic 
drift and founder effects play a major role in speciation (Powell 1978). 
During a founder-flush cycle a new habitat is colonized by a small number 
of individuals (e.g. one inseminated female). The population rapidly 
expands (the flush phase). This is followed by the population crashing. 
During this crash period the population experiences strong genetic drift. 
The population undergoes another rapid expansion followed by another crash. 
This cycle repeats several times. Reproductive isolation is produced as a 
byproduct of genetic drift.

Dood and Powell (1985) tested this hypothesis using D. pseudoobscura. A 
large, heterogenous population was allowed to grow rapidly in a very large 
population cage. Twelve experimental populations were derived from this 
population from single pair matings. These populations were allowed to 
flush. Fourteen months later, mating tests were performed among the twelve 
populations. No postmating isolation was seen. One cross showed strong 
behavioral isolation. The populations underwent three more flush-crash 
cycles. Forty-four months after the start of the experiment (and fifteen 
months after the last flush) the populations were again tested. Once again, 
no postmating isolation was seen. Three populations showed behavioral 
isolation in the form of positive assortative mating. Later tests between 
1980 and 1984 showed that the isolation persisted, though it was weaker in 
some cases.

Galina, et. al. (1993) performed similar experiments with D. pseudoobscura. 
Mating tests between populations that underwent flush-crash cycles and 
their ancestral populations showed 8 cases of positive assortative mating 
out of 118 crosses. They also showed 5 cases of negative assortative mating 
(i.e. the flies preferred to mate with flies of the other strain). Tests 
among the founder-flush populations showed 36 cases of positive assortative 
mating out of 370 crosses. These tests also found 4 cases of negative 
assortative mating. Most of these mating preferences did not persist over 
time. Galina, et. al. concluded that the founder-flush protocol yields 
reproductive isolation only as a rare and erratic event.

Ahearn (1980) applied the founder-flush protocol to D. silvestris. Flies 
from a line of this species underwent several flush-crash cycles. They were 
tested in mate choice experiments against flies from a continuously large 
population. Female flies from both strains preferred to mate with males 
from the large population. Females from the large population would not mate 
with males from the founder flush population. An asymmetric reproductive 
isolation was produced.

In a three year experiment, Ringo, et. al. (1985) compared the effects of a 
founder-flush protocol to the effects of selection on various traits. A 
large population of D. simulans was created from flies from 69 wild caught 
stocks from several locations. Founder-flush lines and selection lines were 
derived from this population. The founder-flush lines went through six 
flush-crash cycles. The selection lines experienced equal intensities of 
selection for various traits. Mating test were performed between strains 
within a treatment and between treatment strains and the source population. 
Crosses were also checked for postmating isolation. In the selection lines, 
10 out of 216 crosses showed positive assortative mating (2 crosses showed 
negative assortative mating). They also found that 25 out of 216 crosses 
showed postmating isolation. Of these, 9 cases involved crosses with the 
source population. In the founder-flush lines 12 out of 216 crosses showed 
positive assortative mating (3 crosses showed negative assortative mating). 
Postmating isolation was found in 15 out of 216 crosses, 11 involving the 
source population. They concluded that only weak isolation was found and 
that there was little difference between the effects of natural selection 
and the effects of genetic drift."

*House Flies:*
"Soans, et. al. (1974) used houseflies to test Pimentel's model of 
speciation. This model posits that speciation requires two steps. The first 
is the formation of races in subpopulations. This is followed by the 
establishment of reproductive isolation. Houseflies were subjected to 
intense divergent selection on the basis of positive and negative geotaxis. 
In some treatments no gene flow was allowed, while in others there was 30% 
gene flow. Selection was imposed by placing 1000 flies into the center of a 
108 cm vertical tube. The first 50 flies that reached the top and the first 
50 flies that reached the bottom were used to found positively and 
negatively geotactic populations."

"Halliburton and Gall (1981) established a population of flour beetles 
collected in Davis, California. In each generation they selected the 8 
lightest and the 8 heaviest pupae of each sex. When these 32 beetles had 
emerged, they were placed together and allowed to mate for 24 hours. Eggs 
were collected for 48 hours. The pupae that developed from these eggs were 
weighed at 19 days. This was repeated for 15 generations. The results of 
mate choice tests between heavy and light beetles was compared to tests 
among control lines derived from randomly chosen pupae. Positive 
assortative mating on the basis of size wat found in 2 out of 4 
experimental lines."

*Flour Beetles:*
"Halliburton and Gall (1981) established a population of flour beetles 
collected in Davis, California. In each generation they selected the 8 
lightest and the 8 heaviest pupae of each sex. When these 32 beetles had 
emerged, they were placed together and allowed to mate for 24 hours. Eggs 
were collected for 48 hours. The pupae that developed from these eggs were 
weighed at 19 days. This was repeated for 15 generations. The results of 
mate choice tests between heavy and light beetles was compared to tests 
among control lines derived from randomly chosen pupae. Positive 
assortative mating on the basis of size wat found in 2 out of 4 
experimental lines."

*Lab Rat Worms:*
"In 1964 five or six individuals of the polychaete worm, Nereis acuminata, 
were collected in Long Beach Harbor, California. These were allowed to grow 
into a population of thousands of individuals. Four pairs from this 
population were transferred to the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute. For 
over 20 years these worms were used as test organisms in environmental 
toxicology. From 1986 to 1991 the Long Beach area was searched for 
populations of the worm. Two populations, P1 and P2, were found. Weinberg, 
et. al. (1992) performed tests on these two populations and the Woods Hole 
population (WH) for both postmating and premating isolation. To test for 
postmating isolation, they looked at whether broods from crosses were 
successfully reared. The results below give the percentage of successful 
rearings for each group of crosses.
WH X WH 75% P1 X P2 77%
P1 X P1 95% WH X P1 0%
P2 X P2 80% WH X P2 0%
They also found statistically significant premating isolation between the 
WH population and the field populations. Finally, the Woods Hole population 
showed slightly different karyotypes from the field populations."

I grew up loving science/nature and strongly believing in evolution. After 
studying the evolution/creation debate I switched to rejecting evolution 
and believing in design. I was super excited about it and studied it a lot 
for several years. Now I am just apathetic and don't really get excited 
about any theory of our existence. I basically am ok with the fact that I 
don't know. But you seem to be very sure of yourself; however, the things 
you write don't give a good foundation for being so sure.
1. In this one you misconstrue evidence, fact, theory, and how these terms 
and ideas are used in science. There is evidence for the expansion of the 
universe. The expansion itself is not a scientific fact or law. It is a 
theory. That doesn't mean it isn't true. The theory of the expansion of the 
universe is just the best overall idea that explains observations that have 
been made. Many of those observation themselves are reliant on assumptions. 
So it is inaccurate to say, "we know it happened because of the evidence." 
It is more accurate to say, "We have a theory that it happened until there 
is overwhelming evidence that our theory is incorrect." There is evidence 
against it and other theories about the nature of the universe. Take some 
time to check them out. You may not believe them, or you may see that there 
always seems to be some conflicting evidence about the expansion. So to sum 
it up regarding the big bang: We have many observations that we interpret 
in a particular way that supports an expanding universe. We take these 
interpretations, along with other interpreted evidence and create a theory 
about the big bang. That is a long way from saying that we KNOW the big 
bang happened.
2. Here again you say, "We know it happened because of the evidence." You 
again misconstrue knowing things with having theories that seem to do a 
good or a great job of explaining observations and interpretations of 
observations. It is a fact that there is gravitational attraction between 
matter. It is a fact that I am sitting in a chair. Macro-evolution is not 
the same as these facts. Macro-evolution may well be true, but we don't 
KNOW that. And saying that breeding chihuahuas out of wolves doesn't 
provide hard evidence for macro-evolution. Going from a wolf to a dog is 
WAY WAY different than going from nothing and getting a super-complex 
creature like a dog. Perhaps you haven't studied biology, anatomy and 
physiology, and molecular biology enough to understand the SUPER-complexity 
of life. But all that SUPER-complexity existed in the wolf. We just 
manipulated the expression of genes to get to a dog. It is amazing the 
changes we have made in the creature, but that manipulation didn't really 
create anything. It just selected some very interesting traits. Basically 
every system in a living creature is necessary for its survival. That goes 
all the way down to each and every molecular structure and chemical 
cascade, up through all the thousands and thousands of super complex 
molecular machines, up to the highly specialized tissues, up through the 
very awesomely designed organs, up through the body systems, up to the 
entire creature and how everything is put together and operates together, 
and even up through how the creature interacts with the outside world 
(breeding, eating, finding shelter, its social habits, and everything else 
that a creature or a population does to survive). Just 1 problem in any one 
of these things and the creature usually cannot live and reproduce. To say 
that random point mutations in a gene code (that's assume how the super 
awesome and complex gene code and its operating mechanisms even got there 
in the first place) can create delicate complexity of this magnitude is a 
stretch beyond credibility. I understand the evidence for evolution. But 
one must consider the counter-evidence as well. Tell me how a nephron 
evolved? or a juxtaglomerular apparatus (google it)?  These are 
multi-faceted mechanisms that derive there function from interrelated, 
complex parts. That HAVE NO FUNCTION unless everything is in place and 
working all at once. So how can a random point mutation create something 
like that. And what came first, the the apparatus or the need for it. If 
the need for it came first, the creature wouldn't survive, because the 
reason for its existence is to correct an imbalance that would quickly kill 
the creature. The two apparatuses that I named here are only 2 parts of a 
kidney. There are many more of equal necessity and complexity in the kidney 
alone. And hundreds of thousands in the entire creature. Each needs to work 
nearly perfectly, all together, to have a living creature. All were 
existent in the original wolf, and all are still there in modern/common 
dog. 
3. You're right about this one; but I think it was more of a joke.
4. Again, your right about that as well.
5. He is not completely off base about his analogy of natural selection to 
quality assurance in a factory. That analogy holds water, and it 
demonstrates that a selection process only selects out the bad things to 
get rid of. It doesn't provide explanatory power for the creation of new 
designs. In evolutionary theory, the power for the new designs is credited 
(I think wrongly) to random point mutations in the gene code. That was the 
supposed beauty of Darwin's theory. It took random changes (although he 
didn't know the mechanism) and subjected it to selection. He thought that 
that was the explanation of how life came to be as we see it today. But, we 
know that selecting itself doesn't create anything. And I think that random 
point mutations cannot account for the complexity we observe in nature. 
(Also, you can think about evolution in the abstract while excluding 
natural selection. If random point mutation was creating anything, it would 
occur even without natural selection. The old things would still exist, but 
a segment of the population would SUPPOSEDLY be changing into new things. 
The natural selection molds and shapes the viable changes from the 
available choices that mutations create, but the mutations are the key for 
providing the choices or possibilities that the selections process can work 
on. Its the same with the human/monkey question (if humans came from 
monkeys, why are there still monkeys) All the monkey like creatures didn't 
have to be selected out for the humans to evolve up the ladder (I realize 
evolution isn't necessarily an UPWARD movement). The same goes for all the 
other natural selection that didn't have to occur for other creatures to 
have emerged. Natural selection supposedly did shape and select what we see 
today. But it isn't a necessary mechanism for chance. Without it, we would 
have just seen other, different creatures. But, to get back to the original 
point; I think that you are wrong in saying that his analogy is off-base. 
It does its job of demonstrating the point he was making. If you don't 
understand that point, then that is your short-coming, not the analogies. 

If you read all of that, way to go. I hope that you consider what I have 
written. And feel free to respond with any well thought-out reply.
Peace.

Here's an explanation of how the basics of carbon dating works from 
wikipedia:

Radiocarbon dating is a radiometric dating method that uses (14C) to 
determine the age of carbonaceous materials up to about 60,000 years old. 
The technique was developed by Willard Libby and his colleagues in 1949[7] 
during his tenure as a professor at the University of Chicago. Libby 
estimated that the radioactivity of exchangeable carbon-14 would be about 
14 disintegrations per minute (dpm) per gram of pure carbon, and this is 
still used as the activity of the modern radiocarbon standard.[8][9] In 
1960, Libby was awarded the Nobel Prize in chemistry for this work.
One of the frequent uses of the technique is to date organic remains from 
archaeological sites. Plants fix atmospheric carbon during photosynthesis, 
so the level of 14C in plants and animals when they die approximately 
equals the level of 14C in the atmosphere at that time. However, it 
decreases thereafter from radioactive decay, allowing the date of death or 
fixation to be estimated. The initial 14C level for the calculation can 
either be estimated, or else directly compared with known year-by-year data 
from tree-ring data (dendrochronology) up to 10,000 years ago (using 
overlapping data from live and dead trees in a given area), or else from 
cave deposits (speleothems), back to about 45,000 years before the present. 
A calculation or (more accurately) a direct comparison of carbon-14 levels 
in a sample, with tree ring or cave-deposit carbon-14 levels of a known 
age, then gives the wood or animal sample age-since-formation.
